Introduction

Genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM), previously known as vulvovaginal atrophy, is a condition characterized by thinning, drying, and inflammation of the vulva, labia, vaginal introitus, urethra, and bladder due to low estrogen levels.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Estrogen plays a critical role in maintaining the thickness, elasticity, and lubrication of the vaginal epithelium.  In addition, it stimulates proliferation of the vaginal epithelium, promotes glycogen deposition, and helps maintain the acidic pH of the vagina through the metobolic action of normal vaginal flora (ie, lactobacilli).



In patients with GSM, reduced estrogen levels associated with menopause cause decreased blood flow and reduced collagen and glycogen content in vulvovaginal tissues.  This condition results in thin vulvar skin with reduced elasticity and loss of vaginal tissue pliability that cause vaginal pruritus and dyspareunia.  Due to the proximity of the bladder to the vaginal epithelium, the bladder trigone and urethral epithelium may also atrophy, resulting in dysuria and urinary frequency.  Patients typically have a pale, dry vagina with petechiae (due to easily denuded epithelium) and minimal vaginal discharge with a pH >4.5 (due to decreased lactic acid production from low glycogen content).



Risk factors related to low systemic estrogen levels include:



  • Postmenopausal status (most common)
  • Oophorectomy
  • Breastfeeding (due to prolactin causing hypothalamic GnRH suppression)
  • Chemotherapy or radiation
  • Medications (eg, GnRH agonists, aromatase inhibitors)
  • Tobacco use
  • Lack of sexual activity (reduced blood flow)

Clinical presentation



Many postmenopausal women have atrophic changes and are asymptomatic; however, symptoms are required for the diagnosis of GSM (ie, asymptomatic patients do not require treatment).



Common symptoms include:



  • Vaginal dryness (most common)
  • Vulvovaginal pruritus and burning
  • Dyspareunia (particularly at the introitus with penile insertion)
  • Abnormal vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal bleeding (often postcoital)
  • Decreased lubrication during sexual intercourse; decreased arousal and orgasm
  • Urinary symptoms (eg, dysuria, urgency, nocturia, increased frequency)

Diagnosis, laboratory evaluation, and imaging



The diagnosis of GSM is made clinically, based on history and physical examination.  Physical examination is dependent on degree of atrophy but can include:



  • Loss of pubic hair
  • Loss of labial volume (including possible fusion of the labia minora)
  • Narrowing of the vaginal introitus
  • Loss of vaginal rugae and elasticity
  • Pale vaginal mucosa (with possible petechiae and fissures)
  • Decreased or abnormal vaginal discharge
  • Prominent urethral meatus (including possible eversion or prolapse)


Laboratory evaluation is usually not performed to diagnose GSM but can be performed to rule out other causes, particularly in patients with abnormal vaginal discharge, vaginal bleeding, or urinary symptoms.  Evaluation can include:



  • Vaginal pH:  an elevated pH (>4.5) supports the diagnosis.
  • Wet mount microscopy:  to exclude infectious causes of vaginal discharge.  Patients with GSM often have parabasal cells, decreased superficial cells, and lack of lactobacilli.
  • Urinalysis and urine culture:  to rule out urinary tract infection.


No imaging is required for the diagnosis of GSM.  However, in patients who have vaginal bleeding, pelvic ultrasonography should be performed to evaluate the endometrial thickness for potential endometrial hyperplasia/cancer.  Patients with an endometrial thickness â‰¥4 mm require further evaluation with an endometrial biopsy for histologic evaluation.

Differential diagnosis



  • Vulvovaginal candidiasis:  presents with vulvovaginal pruritus and erythema.  However, an associated thick, white vaginal discharge is also present.
  • Desquamative inflammatory vaginitis:  presents with vulvar pain and copious vaginal discharge but does not distort vulvar architecture.
  • Vulvar lichen sclerosus (
    figure 1
    ):  presents with vulvar pain, pruritus, dyspareunia, and white plaques that can distort the vulvar architecture.  However, it affects only the vulva (ie, does not affect the vagina).
  • Vulvar lichen planus (
    figure 2
    ):  presents with vulvar pain, pruritus, and dyspareunia due to friable vaginal mucosa and stenosis of the vaginal introitus.  However, examination shows glazed, brightly erythematous vulvar erosions with a border of serpentine-appearing, white striae (ie, Wickham striae).
  • Vaginal or vulvar cancer:  can present with vulvar pain and irritation; however, patients typically have a distinct unifocal plaque.
  • Contact dermatitis:  can occur due to irritants or allergens (eg, soaps, perineal pads, spermicides, lubricants, tight-fitting/synthetic clothing) and typically presents with pruritus.  Contact dermatitis can be distinguished from GSM by resolution of symptoms after removal of potential irritants.

Management



Treatment of GSM is primarily for symptom relief.



For all patients with symptoms, first-line treatment is with nonhormonal therapy such as vaginal moisturizers and lubricants, which provide relief from vaginal dryness and dyspareunia.  In addition, lifestyle modifications such as regular sexual intercourse, avoidance of irritants (eg, perfumed soaps, douching), and pelvic floor exercises are recommended.



In patients with no symptom improvement, vaginal estrogen therapy (eg, cream, tablet, ring) is prescribed, which increases blood flow and glycogen content to the vulvovaginal tissues.  Even at low doses, vaginal estrogen can be systemically absorbed, so it should be used with caution in patients with contraindications to estrogen therapy (eg, thromboembolism, estrogen-dependent cancer).  However, the vaginal estrogen is not absorbent enough to raise concern for possible endometrial cancer, and progestin therapy is not required in patients using only vaginal estrogen.  In addition, vaginal estrogen can also be used as adjuvant therapy in patients using systemic hormone replacement therapy (HRT) because HRT is not as effective in the treatment of GSM.



Other therapies that can be used in patients with moderate to severe GSM symptoms include ospemifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), and prasterone, a vaginal dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA).

Prognosis



Without treatment, symptoms of GSM persist and can dramatically worsen, leading to increased discomfort and complications such as recurrent urinary tract infections and sexual dysfunction.



However, with appropriate treatment, symptoms of GSM can be effectively managed, significantly improving quality of life.  Long-term treatment and regular follow-up are often needed to prevent symptom progression.

Summary



Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is characterized by thinning, drying, and inflammation of the vulva, labia, vaginal introitus, urethra, and bladder due to low estrogen levels (
